title: Tuesday, 19th February 2019
bodyHTML:

11:13 am

Pharma Baseball - proof that statistics can make even the most boring of sports really boring.
BE11:14am

Q4's bad. Massive miss.

BE11:14am

Market pressure is as reported by everyone.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

The bigger surprise is poor numbers from Wealth, specifically Insurance and in Asia.

BE11:16am

Merrill can summarise in a sentence.

BE11:16am

We cut EPS forecasts 4-6% following 4Q 18 results. This takes our Price Objective down 6% to 660p. Downgrade to Neutral. HIBOR weakness should be temporary but is expensive. Global rates drifting lower. Dividend strong support, yield 6%. But earnings momentum has stalled.

11:16 am
BE11:16am

Morgan Stanley can summarise in two sentences.

BE11:17am

4Q18 earnings were a big miss – revenues were lower, costs higher, provisions higher, capital lower. Adjusted revenues were 3% 7% lower than MSE consensus, as market related income was weak. NII missed Adj. costs were 2% higher 1% lower than MSE consensus – driving an 18% PPoP miss vs consensus.
Credit costs were 35 bps (MS/ consensus was ~25 bps), driven by large ECL. CET1 ratio declined 30 bps QoQ. 2019 has started strong; focus will be on big 4Q18 miss – The bank said January 2019 was ahead of plan on revenues. It reiterated guidance for positive jaws in 2019, but given the 4Q18 miss, we think it is unlikely the market will have confidence in this guidance.

BE11:17am

(By sentences I mean paragraphs, don't @ me.)

11:17 am
BE11:17am

Barclays, also two paragraphs.

BE11:17am

Reported Q4 PBT of $3,256m or underlying PBT of $3,387m is a 24% miss or $1,055m below company compiled consensus, driven by revenues 7% light or $908m worse than expected, impairments 34% higher (or $215m) offset by expenses 1% lower ($99m). Within underlying revenues net interest income is a 2% miss or flat q/q, with the revenue miss driven largely by non-interest income (note these include -c$200m of credit/funding/other adjustments). Across divisions, revenues are down 11% q/q in RBWM driven by weakness in WM/insurance, while GBM revenues of $3,063m is down 10% y/y or 27% q/q. Q4 impairments of $853m include a $165m overlay relating to economic uncertainty in the UK. The CET1 ratio of 14.0% is down 30bp q/q driven by dividend, RWA moves and FX. TNAV of $7.01 is in line, flat q/q.

Outlook mixed, we note FX headwind - There is indication of a good start to 2019, with January group revenue performance ahead of plan, and while actual credit performance robust some softening in UK credit performance. For more, see HSBC: Weak China, inverted US Curve - UW, 8th Jan. We calculate that the 2018 revenue base adjusted for current FX rates would be c$1.4bn lower or c2.5%.

Soundbuy Morning - Greggs on a roll..........
BE11:18am

And three more from Citi post the conference call.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Exit NIM Implies Low NII Growth – 4Q18 NIM 1.62% (underlying basis, 1.63% headline) is 5bps lower than 1Q18 NIM of 1.67%. NIMs declined during 2018 despite increase in interest rates: 4Q18 vs 1Q18 moves in average 1M UDS LIBOR +69bps, 1M HKD HIBOR +75bps. The combination of – [1] lower exit NIM for 2018 and [2] tougher interest rate outlook for 2019 relative to 2018, implies a significant NIM headwind YoY for 2019. Consensus for 2019 implies a 6% yoy NII growth. A combination of lower YoY margins with mid-single digit asset growth, reiterated on the analyst call today albeit also challenging given the slower macro environment that management called out, suggests low single digit NII growth for 2019.
 … So High Fee & Trading Growth Needed To Hit Targets – If NII is only set to grow by low single-digits in FY19 it implies other operating income needs to grow by high single-digits, or c$2bn, in order to hit the target mid-single digit revenue growth p.a. In FY18 Wealth only grew by $0.5bn and GBM by $0.2bn, and if anything the environment has become more challenging. Whilst AuM levels have recovered in Jan/Feb 2019, peers have indicated that transaction activity levels are down yoy. Likewise, HSBC management noted that the “good start to 2019” partly reflected revenue slippage from December, so we would be wary to extrapolate this.
 Conclusion: Consensus Revenues Need to Fall – Cons. for FY19 NII is $32.7bn (vs FY18 $30.5bn) and OOI $24.9bn (vs FY18 $23.4bn), or total revenues of $57.6bn (vs FY18 $53.9bn). HSBC’s CFO confirmed that FY19 cons. revenues were too high. Applying the target mid-single digit revenue growth points to adj. revenues of $56.6bn, $1bn shy of cons., and this target looks increasingly difficult to achieve. We therefore expect consensus revenues to fall by closer to c$2bn, which would drive a high single-digit cut to cons. PBT, prior to any offsetting cost flexibility.

BE11:19am

We came away from the HSBC FY18 analyst and earnings call more cautious on the 2019 outlook. The expanding NIM story that helped support the HSBC investment story is now in reverse – and further headwinds on NIM are emerging. Positive ‘jaws’ was missed in 2018 and given the NII headwind will be tough to achieve in 2019 without damaging the franchise which requires ongoing technological and geographic investments. Unlike other large EU/UK listed banks, HSBC trades in-line with its valuation history and not a large discount (current PE vs 5Y median, UK and EU banks trade at c10ppt and c20ppt discount respectively vs close to zero for HSBC). HSBC trades at 11.5x 12m forward cons. P/E and we have a TP of GBp600.

BE11:37am

Overall, a slightly positive set of results. Investor expectations for BHP’s 1H19 financials had been low post the 2Q19 report which missed on a number of divisions and the company guiding cash one-offs, which we believe led to investors concerns about the company’s ability to delever (which it did albeit at a slightly reduced level vs. consensus) and ramp-up returns (which again the company achieved with DPS c. 4% ahead of consensus).
While the numbers are a small beat vs. consensus - we believe that it may be taken as a slight positive today especially given that the expectations going into the results had been low.

wayneJ @red - agreed. But combine with onsite immigration?
VV75 thank youI was thinking of Odey, who now controls 27% in Plus500, I need to figure out his trades
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Key points
Financials: Broadly inline with consensus (Vuma). Revenues were inline with consensus, while EBITDA was a 1% miss. Note that most divisions were a small miss vs. consensus (on EBITDA) but it was offset by the strong performance at the petroleum division - which was a 9% beat.
Returns: Apart from the USc102/shr special dividend, the company announced a USc55/shr dividend which came in 4% higher vs. consensus. This was comprised of of USc37cents +USc18/shr - USc33 is the minimum 50% payout and the USc18cents is the discretionary payout. We believe this is a positive as after the 2Q19 production report, a number of investors had been worried that this could be a disappointment.
Net debt: The company’s net debt came in at US$9.9bn - 6% stronger than our forecast and 2% ahead of consensus. Again this is a positive development as after the 2Q production report - concerns had increased over the company’s ability to generate FCF in this half.
Guidance: a) Capex guidance was unchanged at US$8bn for this year (note that the company did US$3.5bn in 1H). b) Production guidance was the same as 2Q19 production report which was released last month; c)

BE11:40am

Let's try RBC instead. They keep going to a conclusion.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Our view: The half year results saw BHP miss EBITDA by 1% vs RBCe and consensus which grew to a bottom line miss of 4% (vs. RBCe and cons). The underlying result was impacted, as expected, by a challenging operational period with disruptions at Spence, Olympic Dam and WAIO. Strength in the Petroleum division offset weaker financial performance in copper, iron ore and coal. Free cash flow was much better than we had anticipated as a mix of less working capital impacts, lower cash interest charges, and modestly lower capex in the period drove the improved performance. BHP has revised its productivity targets downwards, although this was flagged at the recent operational review. Although it does move from $1bn gain to zero for FY19, this implies a ~$400m gain in H2, which should leave medium-term targets in place. There are no material moves to guidance either on costs or the capex side. The dividend at 157 cents for the period (including the 102 cents from the previously paid special dividend) was also ahead of our estimates at 141 cents and cons at 155 cents.
BHP remains a stalwart and the portfolio reshaping, operational improvements and a focus on capital returns have led the company to a strong position albeit with limited growth prospects (from a scale perspective). Jansen is expected to continue the current slow pace of completion and that option remains open.
Increased investment in the offshore division should help to stem the medium-term field decline but this remains a drag in the short-term.
At 7.1x FY20 EV/EBITDA and 1.23x NAV, on our estimates, with sustained concerns about Chinese demand for iron ore following the Brumadinho driven price spike, and now increasing concerns around Australian coal shipments being held at Chinese ports (Platts reporting Australian cargoes being held up to 60 days), we continue to see the stock as fairly priced. This said, we would expect the market is likely to shrug off this set of slightly weaker results.

The charge is around £100m higher than we hoped, but given end-1H18 net debt was just £53.8m and 1H18 FCF was £9.2m after a spend of £43.8m against onerous contract provisions, we still envisage Cobham ending FY20 in an overtly strong financial position. We put no gloss on events, but still see this as a significant step forward.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

The £160m charge announced today by Cobham cannot be heralded as good news, but we believe the KC-46 completely diverted attention from the fact end 1H18 net debt was just £53.8m, the 1H18 FCF was £9.2m after a spend of £43.8m against onerous contract provisions, and that 1H18 order intake was up 25%. If today's agreement returns the focus to the latter three metrics, we are bound to welcome it as a significant step forward.

Dec69 - Skeptic RW42 yes it's called a financial market with counter parties. Since the dawn of ages theres always been a counterparty.
11:49 am
BE11:49am

Of the £86m to be paid to Boeing to settle the dispute, Cobham can
offset £37m of unpaid CDS invoices leaving £49m to be paid to Boeing in 1H19. The balance of £74m relating to additional costs to complete will likely be spent in FY19 and 1H20. So too may the additional £40m charged announced on 26 July 2018. That said, the 1H18 FCF of £9.2m was after accelerated interest paid of £20.4m implying improved working capital may yet offset some of the incremental cash outflow on KC-46. Ultimately, we believe it is on issues like improving working capital and signs of operational gearing as the higher 1H18 order intake translates into sales that future share price performance hinges. Declaration of a final dividend for FY18 would also send a positive signal, in our view. Exactly what the share price does next may even depend on the tone struck by management at the FY18 results on 7 March 2019; we sense it should be more positive, but are not sure we'd put our shirts on it.

Whilst underlying demand was strong in Q4, the launch of this product has driven the growth rate higher. We have discussed with the company the popularity of the product, and it is clear that this is not simply a product confined to vegan consumers. Whilst we believe that many customers will move on once the ‘hype’ dies down, we also strongly believe that this is opening the Greggs brand to new consumers who have not tried Greggs before (we believe they will be impressed with the quality of offer and every day low price), and customers who have not used Greggs recently. It is likely many of these consumers will be sustained.

This is what we talk about here now. The sausage roll adoption curve.

BE11:57am

When seen through the lens of healthy eating, the interest is intriguing given a vegan roll contains 9.3g of saturated fat (47% “of an adult’s reference intake”), and 1.9g of salt (32% of reference intake). This is below company’s sausage roll saturated fat content of 13g, but above its salt level of 1.6g (source: Greggs’ app). We are big fans of the Greggs offering, believe this product will help deliver better through the cycle profits, but would not advocate chasing shares part way into this ‘gold rush’ given the elevated valuation.

BE12:02pm

Spectris's first set of FY results under new CEO Andrew Heath are encouraging. Results are slightly ahead of expectations at the comparable level, and three of its four divisions are ahead of our divisional profit forecasts (the one that is not - Materials Analysis - is held back by teething problems on the recent acquisition of Concept Life Sciences). Perhaps more important is the outline of where the group goes next: financial reporting will be simplified (with all restructuring costs now taken below the line, and no more Project Uplift), a new £30m cost savings plan has been introduced (with £15-20m of benefit expected to come in 2019), and the group has set out the first conclusions of its strategic review, which suggest that some quite substantial structural changes are envisioned. The aim is to make Spectris a much more focused group. Management have identified three platform businesses on which to build (Malvern Panalytical, HBK and Omega) which together account for over 60% of current group sales. Other businesses will be reviewed with a view to being developed to critical scale or disposed. It is quite a bold plan, and much will come down to detail and execution. The company are planning a CMD in June to add more colour. So far so good - retain Buy.

BE12:03pm

The initial conclusions from the Strategic Review undertaken to-date contain no real surprises. CEO Heath maintains that Spectris has a strong portfolio of businesses, operating in a number of very attractive markets, but there is considerable scope to improve the group's performance/EBITA margins. There is unlikely to be any fundamental shift in strategy, although the group needs to be more focused/simplified, and mgmt. is working towards creating a portfolio of strong businesses that can deliver shareholder value through above-average sales growth, margin expansion and WC efficiency. As part of the portfolio review being undertaken, 3 businesses (Malvern Panalytical, HBK & Omega) have been identified as 'platform businesses' and the remainder of the portfolio is still being reviewed (some of these could still be platform businesses) and will ultimately be managed accordingly - either to deliver on their potential (at least market growth and leading margins) optimise their performance or potentially be sold. Existing capex plans have been reviewed and management's future approach to Capital Allocation will also be more rigorous. There is more work to be done on the Strategic Review and mgmt, will provide "a more comprehensive update" on the outcomes of this review and on strategy at a CMD in June.

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

The outlook commentary gives little away, although mgmt. guide to yoy sales growth in FY19F moderating compared to FY18A (expected), a focus on self-help (top- and bottom-line), with a particular focus on cost savings, improved productivity and operational efficiency. There will be cost inflation/tariffs etc to manage in FY19F, with additional 'growth investment' also expected, but with a focus on cost savings, mgmt. guide to EBITA growing faster than sales in FY19F, hence yoy EBITA margins should rise.

Consensus Forecasts: We expect FY19F consensus EPS (JEFe: 174p, cons: 170p) to move higher post these results, largely as a result of the change of treatment of the Project Uplift charges. Consensus EPS upgrades should be in the mid-single digit region. We also expect consensus net debt to move higher given the FY18 outcome, towards £210-220m.

Now that a generic film appears likely, focus is solely on the launches of Sublocade, and to a lesser extent, Perseris. We expect the ramp in these won't be enough to return to profitability in the next two years, although this depends on capacity for further cost cutting. We expect current c.$700m net cash is enough to sustain the business over this period despite JEFe more than $300m outflow in '19E. We lower EPS on higher costs and PT to 114p. Retain Hold.

BE12:10pm

Assuming that the mandate issues on 19th February, INDV is likely to lose a significant portion of its sales in 2019E and we forecast group sales of $459m vs $1,005m in 2018. The company has guided to $440-460m of operating costs in 2019E (JEFe $444m) and consequently we expect operating loses of c.$60m; we see little improvement in 2020E as in our view further erosion of film sales should mostly offset growth in Sublocade and Perseris. Maintaining cash of more than $250m is critical; we expect more than $300m cash outflow this year, primarily from unwinding of working capital ($271m) and operating losses, while settlement with DoJ and potential damages to DRRD/Alvogen are expected to be phased. Clearly there are significant near-term pressures on the business but we expect current c.$700m net cash position is more than enough to support investments in Sublocade and Perseris launches, especially in light of expected phased payments for any DoJ litigation settlement.
